answers.answer: Hello and Welcome...This could be so many different things.  An eye injury, head injury, Horner's Syndrome, diabetes or hypertension just to name a few.  I'm glad you're getting your boy to the vet today.  I hope it turns out to be nothing too serious.

question: Two months ago my 12 year old male cat started to lose weight.  At first I thought it was because of the dog we rescue and brought home.  That was not a case.  Turned out he really liked the dog and they became friends.  He started to avoid eating a dry food and turned more into the can food.  I just thought he changed his eating habits.  I have 4 cats and now 1 dog (all the rescue animals) so it was really hard for me to notice that something might be wrong. A week ago the right side of his face got swollen and he wouldn’t let me check his mouth.   We took him to the emergency clinic and the vet said he has an infection in his mouth.  He gave him an injection with antibiotic that lasts for 2 weeks in his body and some liquid pain killers to put in his mouth every 8-12 hrs.  He also got some fluids as he was slightly dehydrated.  The next day he felt better and the swelling went down.  3 days later we took him to our regular vet for the check up and the vet said the infection is gone but he has a bad tooth that has to be pulled out.Yesterday I noticed that his condition worsened and he is not eating like always. His right eye is not wide open and today during the day I noticed his pupil is dilated and not reacting to the light.  My question is can a tooth infection cause the eye damage in cats?  Or there is more to it than just a bad tooth.  I would appreciate and answer.We are going to the vet tomorrow for another checkup, but I would like to prepare some questions that should be asked.
title: My cat's one pupil dialated
